intro: Lappula zaissanica, commonly known as the desert lappula, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many other economically important plants. The plant is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and hairy, lobed leaves adapted to conserve water. It typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is well-suited to withstand drought conditions. Lappula zaissanica plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for small desert organisms.
